metadata.title: How to Write YouTube Hooks 2025: First 30 Seconds Guide
metadata.description: Write hooks that keep viewers watching. First 30 seconds strategies that work.

hero.headline: How to Write YouTube Hooks
hero.subheadline: The first 30 seconds determine if viewers stay or leave. Make them count.

sections.content: Your hook is everything. Most viewers decide within seconds whether to keep watching. A weak start kills otherwise great videos. Strong hooks grab attention, create curiosity, and make staying feel essential. Here's how to write hooks that work.

content.title: Question Hook
content.description: 'Have you ever wondered...' Opens curiosity loop.

content.title: Problem Hook
content.description: 'Most people get this wrong...' Identifies pain point.

content.title: Promise Hook
content.description: 'By the end, you'll know exactly...' States value.

sections.title: Creating Strong Hooks
content: Open with your strongest point (not intro/greetings)

content.title: Cold Open
content.description: Start mid-action or mid-thought. No setup, just content.

content.title: Teaser
content.description: Show the end result first. 'Here's what we achieved...'

content.title: Stakes Statement
content.description: 'If you don't know this, you're losing...' Create urgency.

faq.question: How long should the hook be?
faq.answer: 5-30 seconds typically. Get to value fast. The hook should flow into content, not be a separate intro.

faq.question: Should I tease the ending?
faq.answer: Often yes—showing results first creates curiosity about how. 'Here's what I built/achieved... let me show you how.'

faq.question: Can I greet viewers at all?
faq.answer: Yes, but after the hook. Deliver value first, then briefly greet if it fits your style. Never lead with greetings.

faq.question: How to test hook effectiveness?
faq.answer: Check retention graph at 30-second mark. High drop-off = weak hook. Compare across videos to find patterns.
